newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: U.S., SWEDEN GIVE $2 MILLION TO IGNALINA.
newsitem.headline: U.S., SWEDEN GIVE $2 MILLION TO IGNALINA.

text.p: The U.S. and Sweden have signed a contract with Lithuania's Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant to improve safety at the Chernobyl-style plant, the economy ministry announced Friday.
"Yesterday...a contract between Swedish International Project, the U.S. Department of Energy and Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant was signed," economy ministry adviser Jonas Kazlauskas told reporters.

"This contract is estimated at $2 million and under it a Configuration Management and Reliability Maintenance Management System will be delivered to the Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant," Kazlauskas said.
"The funds are donated 50 percent by the Swedish party and 50 percent by the American party," Kazlauskas said. "This is a gift to improve safety operations at the nuclear power plant."
The Ignalina plant consists of two units, which were commissioned in December 1983 and August 1987. The plant is expected to be decommissioned early next century.
Ignalina's two Soviet designed RBMK reactors are the largest of their kind.
